title: Cyber Daily: Company Data Hoards Create Tempting Targets for Hackers
text:
Letting information collect is far easier than methodically and continuously sorting through it to discard what isn't in active use. Some managers operate under the principle that just because a data point seems insignificant today doesn't mean it won't be profitable in some future marketing or product development algorithm.

Like bank robbers after money, hackers go where the data is.

Newsletter Extra: What action U.S. officials recommend we do immediately after ranswomare strikes.

More news: U.S. State Department hit by cyberattack; data compromised at Loomis Armored and Las Vegas medical center; sneaky botnet; no more anonymity on Binance crypto exchange; and more.

Cybercriminals' Ten Favorite Industries

The list may surprise you.... New avenues of attack, brought forth by the COVID-19 pandemic, threaten life online as we now know it.

Read more

Ripe Targets

T-Mobile is just one example. The hoards of consumer information that companies collect multiply the damaging effects of data breaches. In an estimated 1,700 publicly reported data breaches during the first half of 2021, more than 18 billion pieces of information have been exposed, according to research from cybersecurity company Risk Based Security Inc.

Most state laws that recommend curbs on what can be warehoused tend to frame them as best-practice guidelines rather than mandates, said Amy Keller, leader of the cybersecurity and technology law group at DiCello Levitt Gutzler.

"Generally speaking, it's still the Wild West in the U.S. for the types of information that companies can keep on us," said Ms. Keller, who has served as co-lead counsel on class-action lawsuits over data breaches at Equifax Inc ., Marriott International Inc . and Blackbaud Inc .

Read the full story.

Privacy

Patients at risk: An estimated 1.3 million patients had their personal data exposed in a June cyberattack at the University Medical Center of Southern Nevada, the facility disclosed to the Department of Health and Human Services. UMC acknowledged the attack July 29, saying financial, clinical and demographic data were accessed, but at the time it didn't provide a tally of patients affected. Staff members experienced difficulties logging in during the incident but patient care wasn't disrupted, UMC said.

Loomis armored car company email system compromised. Unauthorized access to an employee email account at Loomis Armored US LLC exposed personal data for 87 individuals, including their driver's license numbers. Loomis, based in Houston, said it discovered suspicious activity on its network in December 2020, confirmed the intrusion in May and completed an investigation in June.

Newsletter Extra: Ransomware Response

Caught in a ransomware attack, organizations should take certain immediate steps to secure systems and stop data loss, according to guidance last week from the Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency.

1.

Isolate affected systems. If several systems appear impacted, take the network offline at the switch level. If that isn't possible, unplug affected devices from the network or remove them from Wi-Fi.

2.

Turn off infected devices. This should be done only if they can't be removed from the network or the network can't be temporarily shut down. Know that doing this might result in the loss of infection artifacts and potential evidence stored in volatile memory.

3.

Triage. Prioritize restoration and recovery of impacted systems based on their criticality.

4.

Document what happened. Seek the analysis of team members.

5.

Get help. Inform internal and external teams and stakeholders of how they can help you mitigate, respond to and recover from the incident. Consider requesting assistance from a reputable third-party incident response provider with data-breach experience.

More Cyber News

Anti-money laundering: Customers of Binance will have to submit to tighter scrutiny as regulators in several countries including Germany and Japan pressure the cryptocurrency exchange over money laundering concerns. Users will have to be verified through their identifcation cards, driver's licenses or passports to access the full range range of products and services on Binance. (Reuters)

Cyber attack: The U.S. State Department was recently hit by a cyber attack, and notifications of a possible serious breach were made by the Department of Defense Cyber Command, according to Fox News. The extent of the breach and the perpetrators behind the attack remains unclear at this time. (Fox News)

Tokyo crypto exchange suspends transactions. Liquid Global said it is investigating an incident in which some cryptocurrency wallets were compromised. It has stopped deposits and withdrawals. Blockchain analysis firm Elliptic said about $97 million in various cryptocurrencies was stolen. (InfoSecurity Magazine)

Botnet targets networking gear. A large botnet known as Mozi has modified its malware to remain on networking products from Huawei Technologies Co ., Netgear Inc . and ZTE Corp . even after the devices are rebooted, according to research from Microsoft . (Cyberscoop)
